Ah, Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee. There is much that can be said about this particular gem of a game, good challange, great fun and a lot of old fashioned slapstick humor.
As I play this game I start to reminice, reminice about the old times long past; it began in 1990- something, when I was just an inexperienced youngling with the world ahead of me. I had never heard much of games, save the windows 95 classics such as minesweeper and the like. I remember the cold winter evening when I sat behind the window, about a week earlier we got a letter saying that my father was honorably discharged from the frontlines, and that he would return home.
He had fought the swedes in the attempt to secure Norways freedom. I saw a shade move into the garden, the sound of footsteps pressing their way into the wast snow on the ground. I ran to the door to find my father standing there, standing so proud, yet humble in his fusilier uniform, the musket over his shoulder, and a smile of joy visible through his thick beard. As he stepped into the house I saw a strange gray box in his left hand, a box that would later change my life.
Me and my father played many an hour, many games with this gray box, but the first we ever played was Abe's Oddysee.
It was this game that I played in these dark times, and when I played I knew that some day there would be peace.

It also has a great sequel!

reviewText:
Do you love platformers? Like games with lots of secrets? Need a challenge? Then Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is the game for you. Abe's Oddysee is a 2D sidescrolling cinematic platformer/puzzle game (phew!) with some interesting twists.

Story: You are Abe, a mudokon who works on Rupture Farms. Abe lives a great life, despite being a slave. One day, while roaming the area, Abe finds that Glukkons (the scumbag rich species of Oddworld) want to turn mudokons into food. Abe, finding that out, decides that the best thing to do is save the 99 mudokons in Rupture Farms. Your journey won't be easy, because deadly enemies are almost everywhere.

Gameplay: As I said before, this is a 2D platformer. The game is divided in screens (fixed camera, i,e., go to the right edge of the screen and it moves to the next camera/play area). This system gives the player a sense of suspense, because you never know what's in the next screen. One of the powers Abe has is possessing his enemies. Press the button, wait some seconds, you are controlling the enemy. You can do almost everything with him (kill him, kill other enemies, pull levers, fall off a cliff, you name it!) and it's an helpful power to finish your journey. There is a basic speaking system called GameSpeak that allows to control other mudokons using basic sentences (Hi!, Follow me, wait and even farting!). Mudokons must be moved using this system and taken to the nearest bird portal. Just chant and voila! The portal opens and they're saved! (:D) Unless... they trip on a mine. ( :( ) The only problem this game has in terms of gameplay is that checkpoints are infrequent and sometimes you will have to do same thing again and again only to die in the same place.

Graphics: Even though some screens look 3D, they are actually pre-rendered. The environments are beautiful and varied.

Sound: The soundtrack adds to the atmosphere, and the sound effects are pretty good.

Final thoughts: Despite the somewhat dated graphics, Oddworld is an amazing game. The story is amazing, the gameplay is easy to learn and hard to master, and the soundtrack is pretty good.

One of the greatest platformers of all time. The cinematic style of this game has always astounded me even to this day, the games visual style still holds up today which is good for a playstation one era game. From the dark, dirty factories of Rupture farms to the vast plains of Scrabania, this game is an absoloute pleasure to look at no matter where you go.

The gameplay is another one of this games strongpoints. The game focuses around controlling Abe, trying to escape Rupture Farms and save his Mudokon brothers from slavery by the Glukkons. The gameplay focuses around avoiding your adverseries by any means necessary, as Abe doesnt have a way to attack but that is where possesion comes in.

The controls are amazingly responsive, no real delay or anything which is an essential requirement for a sidescrolling platfromer of this type and Oddwolrd Inhabitants hit the nail on the head with this one. Abe controls just how he should, your main controls are the usual things such as running, sneaking jumping etc.

The tone of the game is also fantastic. The game has a dark overtone through the whole experience, showing how Oddworld is changing and not in a good way. But the game is sort of lightened up with the characters that are presented to us throughout the full game. All the characters are likable in this game in their own way. The Sligs, The Glukkons, The Mudokons and especially Abe himself.

Oddworld Inhabitants managed to create a character that was relatable in his own way, a character that was innocent enough but has been dropped into a situation that is so much bigger than he is. Oddworld Inhabitants have crafted a masterpiece here and i would recommend this game to anybody who loves platformers, action games or even stealth games.

My only complaints have to be the checkpoint system is irritating, with checkpoints being very scarce and this game being very unforgiving with one hit deaths, learning puzzles can be rather difficult. Also not being able to call upon more than one Mudokon at once is kind of annoying. Luckily both of these issues have been fixed in the sequal.

Abe's Oddysee still holds up today and is still one of my favourite games to date and a fantastic addition to the platforming genre. 8/10

I love the Oddworld games, Abe's Oddysee is the first one I have had the chance to play on PC. Abe's  Oddysee is the first Oddworld game released, and the first one I ever played way back on the PlayStation 1. Oddworld games are always filled with dark comedy, the Oddworld games always manage to keep a sense of adventure coupled with a macabre feel that I just love.

In Abe's Oddysee you play a character named Abe, a Mudokon slave worker who uncovers a nefarious plot that could lead to the death of his people. He sets out on a quest to free them, slowly uncovering more of his Mudokon culture along the way.  Gameplay wise Abe's Oddysee is a 2D platformer filled with puzzles and obstacles to complete or circumvent, but remember the ending is dependent on how well you do.

Overall I would recommend Oddworld games to anyone who is a fan of adventure or puzzle games. Oddworld is one of those series that feels really unique, so you'd be challenged to find something close enough to the Oddworld games.

reviewText:
There are few games that can get a person like me misty eyed, but Abe's Oddysee is one of them. To say I have a strong fondness of this game is an understatement; to say I love it still falls short of the entire truth; in fact, any attempt to compose a sentence from the English language expressing how much I admire this game would still miss the mark entirely. When I think about the amazing land of Oddworld filled with Mudokons and Scrabs and... what's that? What's a Mudokon? Oh ho ho, sit down dear child, and listen, listen well, for I have a tale to tell...

Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee (and that is spelled correctly, by the way, it's 'odd'ysee - get it?) is set in the surreal Oddworld, a dystopia where industrial giants destroy the land and enslave the hapless race of Mudokons in order to inflate profit margins; all the while driving races to extinction and marring the pristine surroundings. Sound familiar? Well, that's where the similarity ends, because Mudokons are green alien-looking dudes with sewn lips and the ability to possess certain animals. The industrialists are Glukkons; tall, armless, cigar smokers who wear smart sleeveless suits and have sinister glowing red eyes. The foreboding atmosphere is buttressed by an even more disturbing and darkly comical plot.

Abe, Mudokon 'employee' of the month, is busy waxing the floor of the meat processing giant Rupture Farms when he overhears a board meeting being held by the meanest, most ruthless Glukkon in Oddworld: Molluck. Profits are down because of the steadily declining wildlife they use to create their foodstuffs and the shareholders are going nuts. Molluck calmly divulges his nefarious plan to the wary board members: to save his meat packing empire, he plans on processing Abe and all of his Mudokon pals into delicious meat snacks! Suddenly, Abe is spotted, and considers finding the fastest escape route out of Rupture Farms, but hesitates. He can't just save his own hide; there are 99 other Mudokons who need a savior too!

Abe's Oddysee is a 2D platformer, and a tough one at that. It's similar to the original Prince of Persia with arched jumps, fiendish traps and a duck-n-roll gameplay style; the difference is that Abe has no attacks of his own, and is in fact, completely unarmed. Well, he has one special move, which allows him to posses the Slig guards, hideous slug-like creatures armed with machine guns. This means that Abe relies primarily on stealth, slinking silently in the shadows, occasionally possessing a guard or two in order to solve devilishly hard and ingenious puzzles. A great example of this can be found early in the game; in order for Abe to proceed, he must navigate a series of corridors guarded by patrolling Sligs. How do you deal with such a conundrum? Easy, hide out of the line of machine gun fire, posses a single Slig guard and mow down all the other guards before running the possessed puppet into a meat grinder. Puzzle solved and hilarity ensured. Of course, the puzzles get increasingly more complex, and trying to complete levels can be harder than first perceived, especially when security eventually steps in and prevents you from possessing Sligs.

The only way to master the game is through trial and error. As Abe, you must learn the area layouts and master the timing on encounters. Its reaction based, and you have to develop those lightning fast reflexes quickly because the puzzles have a ridiculously hard learning curve and complete control over Abe is utterly essential in tight situations. You are going to die, a lot, and having to rescue Mudokons on top of everything else just makes it harder to achieve the goal- you can't just run past guards and hope to get lucky - all your mates will become lead pumped corpses if you dare. Completing levels and trying to save Mudokons is a fine line to balance; should you take the morally minded side, then you're in for some expertly crafted and insanely hard mind melting dilemmas. Playing the reluctant hero is not only hard, but it also requires the constant communication between Abe and his chums through the use of Gamespeak, which allows Abe to relay instructions to his posse of frazzled Mudokons - from 'wait' to 'follow', the wearied followers will rely on instructions from him before moving a single muscle. Abe can also fart and whistle but these are less essential, yet still rather amusing, tools.

Now all this is very well and good, but is the game a looker? Well, yes. Yes, it is. The world is incredibly well-realized and the character design is spot-on. The art is amazing and it sucks you in from the start with its portrayal of a gritty industrial hell-world, as well as its brooding temples and wastelands later on. All of the creatures have a worn, dirty look to them and yet even the vicious Scrab wildlife can be both endearing and terrifying. Oddworld is a horrible place to live, and creator Lorne and his development team aren't going to let you forget it. It's difficult to try and encapsulate what a fantastically dark world the developers have created in words, but to see such formidable, soul-chilling environments and creatures balanced by naïve and strangely lovable characters is truly a sight to behold. The art is complimented by sinister, atmospheric musical pieces that builds so much tension it's hard not to break a sweat; long, barren sound-scapes fill the background complete with whirring machinery or cooing wildlife and when the chase is on a fast paced, drum-heavy tribal music kicks in, causing your heart rate to speed up in accordance.

But it's not only the music and sound-scapes that make this an aural pleasure, the voice acting is so marvelous and well suited to the characters its hard not to fear for Abe's pals even after you've logged out of the game. Admittedly, some may think the graphics are a little dated, but if you can put up with a little bit of a blurry resolution, you'll find that the actual animation and backgrounds are created with such flair and originality they possess that most desired of all traits: timelessness. Nothing has made me drop my jaw in astonishment since I saw the graphics for Abe's Oddysee for that first time, and I doubt anything ever will.

Recommendation: Old school platform puzzler for the gamer who wants to live and breathe a world rather than destroy it, but hellishly difficult and perhaps just a little bit too steep a learning curve for most.

Bottom Line: The tough but rewarding gameplay coupled with the most amazing story telling and beautiful environments make this a landmark in gaming history and one you should all go take note of. Go and get this game, by buying, begging or burglary, just find a way to play this wonderful piece of gaming.

reviewText:
I remember buying this game back when it was released for the PlayStation 1. As far as I remember, it was a popular release and it received many positive reviews by the major publications of the time. I was excited to buy it but as soon as I began playing it, I remember being disappointed. I can't remember whether or not I beat it back then but chances are high that I got bored and quit playing just as I did now.

Despite what the multitude of nostalgic, rabid and headstrong fans say, Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee  didn't age well at all from what was already a mediocre effort to begin with. While the character design is interesting and charming, everything else is quite flawed. The background graphics and animations are average to below average, the music is nearly non-existent, the sound effects can get borderline annoying at times, and worst of all, the controls are extremely unresponsive, sluggish and awkward. Getting Abe to perform the most basic of platforming moves such as seamlessly running, stopping, climbing on a ledge and then sneaking is painful and inadequate. Controlling Abe feels very much delayed and as if the movements were restricted in some way. The puzzles and rooms are designed competently for the most part but when you have to deal with the game's awful controls, solving each screen is too aggravating and devoid of any fun whatsoever. The gameplay revolves around traversing the game world one screen at a time. Even though not every screen presents the player with a puzzle or a situation that needs his or her attention, there is still the need to advance through each screen individually and with a slight pause between each transition. Deaths come often and the player will be forced to repeatedly wait through a lengthy death and restart animation that takes about five seconds to complete. The save system is based on checkpoints, so if the player dies several screens beyond the last checkpoint, every screen from the checkpoint to the point of death will need to be redone as many times as it takes until you reach the next checkpoint. Without mentioning any spoilers, it is encouraged that there is at least one additional playthrough after you beat the game once. In relation to this, one of the worst design choices in the game presents itself. The goal is to rescue slaves. Unfortunately for the player, many of the slaves are hidden away in secret areas that are absolutely not easy to find. Thanks to this design decision, this means the player will fail at the goal the game has set to be accomplished.

It's surprising to me how much love Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee has garnered through the years. It has far too many flaws to be enjoyed and it's way too annoying to be played to completion. This game could easily have been so much better than it actually is.

Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee is mediocre.

reviewText:
Intense platforming with a charming funny world and inhabitents.

Fun is ruined by an inconsistent saving system.  Death comes easy and fast but returning to where you died to try again can take a frustratingly long time.  A quick save would have fixed this, but no such option exists.

Designed to be harsh but completely at the expense of fun.  Each death can reset a considerable amount of progress - to the point of being unfair.

The later iterations have fixed this, but this 1997 version has little respect for your time.  I find it impossible to recommend because the genre (punishing game play that teaches through deaths) has been far more refined in modern games.

Claims of this being 'hardcore' or for 'oldschool' players aren't made by those who value their time.

But after dying a couple dozen times in a row in the same spot early in the game because the finicky controls make success seemingly impossible, I must give up on it, and reluctantly give it the thumbs down.  Maybe the remake is improved?  One can hope, but I have seen a fair bit of negativity about it.

reviewText: Dat Nostalgia

Abe's Oddysee... a game that changed my pathetic little life so much that I became a cool kid instantly.

The atmosphere is perfect, the music builds and releases so much tension. The gameplay is at a quick and gut busting pace with slow and high tension sneaking parts slapped in. Defusing bombs will leave a line of sweat running down your head and guiding each mudokkon to the bird portals is another notch on the belt that is your ever extending sympathetic exsistance.

Your are a messiah sent to free your spirtual speices from the deathgrip of the industrious Glukkon, Magog Cartel.
You and everyone around you is a slave to the meat factory that is about to start serving them as the main course, due to lack in sales and depletting numbers of the local wildlife.

If you couldn't tell this game has tons of messages written in and compares to a lot of real world problems, but the cool part is you can completely ignore it all and still play this amazing 2-D screen-to-screen platformer.

The character animations are fluid and controls have a somewhat high learning curve, but also a diverse and streamed lined running and jumping system once you learn them completely.

There are a few bugs in this game, but none of them are game breaking in the sense that you can't just replay that section... and actually most bugs just leave me laughing my ♥♥♥ off.

It is fun to talk to the gaurds and other mudokkons with the genius game-speak. (although you can only talk to one person at a time *fixed in the second game*)

There is one good and bad ending to this game depending on if you are nice and save people or a big meany that goes around killing all your fellow peoples. Oh and did I mention the cutscenes were legendary for their time... and IMHO still hold up today and look terrific.

This game is hard, but no worry as you have infinite lifes and restart at specific check point locations. In the second game they upped the difficulty, but also added a quick save feature.

Try it out... it will make you laugh, cry, scream, and say OH ♥♥♥♥ OH ♥♥♥♥ OH ♥♥♥♥!!! Truely a master peice in my eyes.

This, alongside Abe's Exoddus, is a must have for anyone looking for an exciting, fun, amusing and challenging game. The world is beautiful, the story is riveting and deep, even philosophical if you look deep enough, and the characters are engaging and easy to become attached to, and this runs right throughout the Oddworld series. Abe's Oddysee is a masterpiece of satire, dark humour and social commentary. One of the few video games to tackle serious real-world issues, Oddysee shines a darkly comedic yet sickly light on the cruelties of factory farming, as well as the exploitation of native cultures and wildlife by corporate greed. The game deals with the dichotomy of industrial and spiritual world views, and places us into a violent, weird and odd world. Just like our own.

While these meanings and intentions are confirmed and stem from Oddworld's brainchild Lorne Lanning, all of this is likely lost on most of Oddworld's audience. It certainly was lost on me when I played it as a small child. However, Oddworld Inhabitants provided an exciting, intruiging and challenging experience in Oddysee whether or not the meanings were decoded. And later on, when the messages become more prevalent, it simply gives us more to talk about, and furthers the cause of games as effective, communicative art.

Overall, Abe's Oddysee is a great game with a compelling setting and story. Exoddus is a brilliant follow-up, with more of the same. Both highly recommended and unexpectedly intelligent gems.

Abe's Oddysee is a masterpiece of a game. From the simple but challenging puzzle based gameplay, to the heady artstyle, to the rich world, to the deep and compelling storyline. Everything about this game fits together perfectly in a way that stands the test of time in a way few games from that era do.


The premise is simple, you play as Abe, A Mudoken slave worker working for the meat processing facility, Rupture Farms. After farming other species to near extinction in service of profit, The tyrannical Glukkon overlords decide to turn their slave workers into their next New 'n Tasty delight. After learning this, Abe decides to escape and try and save some of his fellow workers along the way. The dark thematic elements of the story juxtaposed with the cutesey artstyle and adorable haiku's narrated by Abe goes hand in hand and works on so many levels. The game gives you a glimpse of this diverse, incongruous world and makes you want to know more about what lays beyond.


The gameplay involves you traversing through 2-D environments, avoiding traps and enemies while also leading your fellow mudoken's to safety. Everything you see in the game is tile based. You press forward once, you move forward one tile. When you jump, you jump three tiles ahead and more when you get a running start. It's all very simple. Where the beauty lays is in the specificity required to complete the increasingly complex puzzles. In the later stages you'll be required to complete screen after screen after screen of challenging platforming levels without resbite where the slightest mistake will send you right to the begining with nobody to blame but yourself. The controls are so tight that when you do eventually overcome an obstacle, the feeling of satisfaction is immense. It's something that's kept me coming back to this game for over a decade.


While the remake doesn't quite capture the nuance of the platforming the way I'd like, It manages to recapture a lot of the narrative hooks that, well, hooked me and is absolutley worth a shot but nothing can compare to the purity of the original.

Abe's Oddysee is a masterpiece of satire, dark humour and social commentary. One of the few video games to tackle serious real-world issues, Oddysee shines a darkly comedic yet sickly light on the cruelties of factory farming, as well as the exploitation of native cultures and wildlife by corporate greed. The game deals with the dichotomy of industrial and spiritual world views, and places us into a violent, weird and odd world. Just like our own.

While these meanings and intentions are confirmed and stem from Oddworld's brainchild Lorne Lanning, all of this is likely lost on most of Oddworld's audience. It certainly was lost on me when I played it as a small child. However, Oddworld Inhabitants provided an exciting, intruiging and challenging experience in Oddysee whether or not the meanings were decoded. And later on, when the messages become more prevalent, it simply gives us more to talk about, and furthers the cause of games as effective, communicative art.

Overall, Abe's Oddysee is a great game with a compelling setting and story. Exoddus is a brilliant follow-up, with more of the same. Both highly recommended and unexpectedly intelligent gems.
